citations.acs_citation: Eastman, P., Behara, P.K., Dotson, D.L. et al. SPICE, A Dataset of Drug-like Molecules and Peptides for Training Machine Learning Potentials. Sci Data 10, 11 (2023). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-022-01882-6
citations.bibtex: @article{eastman_spice_2023, title = {{SPICE}, {A} {Dataset} of {Drug}-like {Molecules} and {Peptides} for {Training} {Machine} {Learning} {Potentials}}, volume = {10}, copyright = {2022 The Author(s)}, issn = {2052-4463}, url = {https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-022-01882-6}, doi = {10.1038/s41597-022-01882-6}, abstract = {Machine learning potentials are an important tool for molecular simulation, but their development is held back by a shortage of high quality datasets to train them on. We describe the SPICE dataset, a new quantum chemistry dataset for training potentials relevant to simulating drug-like small molecules interacting with proteins. It contains over 1.1 million conformations for a diverse set of small molecules, dimers, dipeptides, and solvated amino acids. It includes 15 elements, charged and uncharged molecules, and a wide range of covalent and non-covalent interactions. It provides both forces and energies calculated at the ωB97M-D3(BJ)/def2-TZVPPD level of theory, along with other useful quantities such as multipole moments and bond orders. We train a set of machine learning potentials on it and demonstrate that they can achieve chemical accuracy across a broad region of chemical space. It can serve as a valuable resource for the creation of transferable, ready to use potential functions for use in molecular simulations.}, language = {en}, number = {1}, urldate = {2023-01-07}, journal = {Scientific Data}, author = {Eastman, Peter and Behara, Pavan Kumar and Dotson, David L. and Galvelis, Raimondas and Herr, John E. and Horton, Josh T. and Mao, Yuezhi and Chodera, John D. and Pritchard, Benjamin P. and Wang, Yuanqing and De Fabritiis, Gianni and Markland, Thomas E.}, month = jan, year = {2023}, note = {Number: 1 Publisher: Nature Publishing Group}, keywords = {Proteins, Molecular dynamics, Computational chemistry, Density functional theory}, pages = {11}, }

data.description: Small organic molecules with up to 9 heavy atoms sampled from PubChemQC. This dataset is analagous to QM9, but represents greater chemical diversity. Ground state and orbital properties are available at the B3LYP/6-31G* level of theory. All molecules are neutral, but some are doublets and triplets. This dataset is also available on FigShare.
data.name: PC9
data.tagline: A diverse subset of PubChemQC containing up to 9 heavy atoms.

data.description: Small water clusters of between 1 and 21 molecules, sampled using the metadynamics strategy (described in the citations). Energies, gradients, and dipole moments are provided at the ωB97X-D/6-311G** level of theory. Entries with the "bowlk" suffix were sampled subject to a restraining spring force with a force constant of either 0.07 or 0.1 Hartree/Angstrom<sup>2</sup>.
data.name: TensorMol Water Clusters
data.tagline: Clusters of 1 to 21 water molecules, sampled with metadynamics.

data.description: A member of the COMP6 benchmark set, this dataset contains off-equilibrium conformations for 2,500 molecules with 10 to 13 heavy atoms subsampled from the GDB-13 data set. data.name: COMP6 GDB10to13
data.tagline: Benchmark containing off-equilibrium molecules from GDB13 with 10 to 13 heavy atoms.

data.name: SN2 Reactions
data.tagline: Chemical reactions of methyl halides with halide anions

data.description: Molecular dynamics trajectories of small molecules: benzene, uracil, naphthalene, aspirin, salicylic acid malonaldehyde, ethanol, toluene, paracetamol, azobenzene, aspirin, toluene, and ethanol. Four levels of theory are available: PBE-TS, CCSD/cc-pVDZ, CCSD(T)/cc-pVDZ, and CCSD(T)/cc-pVTZ. Trajectories at the DFT level contain 105-106 geometries. data.description: Small organic molecules with up to 7 heavy atoms, sampled from GDB-13 and optimized at the PBE0 level of theory. Ground and excited state properties are evaluated at the PBE0, ZINDO, and GW levels of theory. This dataset was sourced from quantum-machine.org and qmml.org.
data.name: QM7b
data.tagline: Small organic molecules with up to 7 heavy atoms with excited state properties.

citations.acs_citation: Eastman, P., Behara, P.K., Dotson, D.L. et al. SPICE, A Dataset of Drug-like Molecules and Peptides for Training Machine Learning Potentials. Sci Data 10, 11 (2023). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-022-01882-6
citations.bibtex: @article{eastman_spice_2023, title = {{SPICE}, {A} {Dataset} of {Drug}-like {Molecules} and {Peptides} for {Training} {Machine} {Learning} {Potentials}}, volume = {10}, copyright = {2022 The Author(s)}, issn = {2052-4463}, url = {https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-022-01882-6}, doi = {10.1038/s41597-022-01882-6}, abstract = {Machine learning potentials are an important tool for molecular simulation, but their development is held back by a shortage of high quality datasets to train them on. We describe the SPICE dataset, a new quantum chemistry dataset for training potentials relevant to simulating drug-like small molecules interacting with proteins. It contains over 1.1 million conformations for a diverse set of small molecules, dimers, dipeptides, and solvated amino acids. It includes 15 elements, charged and uncharged molecules, and a wide range of covalent and non-covalent interactions. It provides both forces and energies calculated at the ωB97M-D3(BJ)/def2-TZVPPD level of theory, along with other useful quantities such as multipole moments and bond orders. We train a set of machine learning potentials on it and demonstrate that they can achieve chemical accuracy across a broad region of chemical space. It can serve as a valuable resource for the creation of transferable, ready to use potential functions for use in molecular simulations.}, language = {en}, number = {1}, urldate = {2023-01-07}, journal = {Scientific Data}, author = {Eastman, Peter and Behara, Pavan Kumar and Dotson, David L. and Galvelis, Raimondas and Herr, John E. and Horton, Josh T. and Mao, Yuezhi and Chodera, John D. and Pritchard, Benjamin P. and Wang, Yuanqing and De Fabritiis, Gianni and Markland, Thomas E.}, month = jan, year = {2023}, note = {Number: 1 Publisher: Nature Publishing Group}, keywords = {Proteins, Molecular dynamics, Computational chemistry, Density functional theory}, pages = {11}, }

citations.acs_citation: Unke, O. T. & Meuwly, M. Solvated protein fragments. Zenodo, 2019.

data.description: Water-solvated protein fragements with up to 8 heavy atoms. Configurations are generated from MD, evaluated at the revPBE-D3(BJ)/def2-TZVP level of theory. Also included are fragment dimers and clusters of up to 40 water molecules. This dataset was sourced from quantum-machine.org.
data.name: Solvated Protein Fragments
data.tagline: Amons derived from proteins, in water.

citations.acs_citation: Smith, J. S.; Nebgen, B.; Lubbers, N.; Isayev, O. & Roitberg, A. E. Less is more: Sampling chemical space with active learning. J. Chem. Phys., 2018, 148, 241733.

data.description: A member of the COMP6 benchmark set, this dataset contains MD trajectories generated using the ANI-1x potential at 300K for 14 drug molecules and two peptides. Each trajectory is 128 frames subsampled from 1 ns of dynamics. Reference calculations are performed at the ωB97x/6-31g* level of theory. All molecules are neutral singlets. This dataset was sourced from GitHub.
data.name: COMP6 ANI-MD
data.tagline: Benchmark containing MD trajectories from the ANI-1x potential.

citations.bibtex: @article{eastman_spice_2023, title = {{SPICE}, {A} {Dataset} of {Drug}-like {Molecules} and {Peptides} for {Training} {Machine} {Learning} {Potentials}}, volume = {10}, copyright = {2022 The Author(s)}, issn = {2052-4463}, url = {https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-022-01882-6}, doi = {10.1038/s41597-022-01882-6}, abstract = {Machine learning potentials are an important tool for molecular simulation, but their development is held back by a shortage of high quality datasets to train them on. We describe the SPICE dataset, a new quantum chemistry dataset for training potentials relevant to simulating drug-like small molecules interacting with proteins. It contains over 1.1 million conformations for a diverse set of small molecules, dimers, dipeptides, and solvated amino acids. It includes 15 elements, charged and uncharged molecules, and a wide range of covalent and non-covalent interactions. It provides both forces and energies calculated at the ωB97M-D3(BJ)/def2-TZVPPD level of theory, along with other useful quantities such as multipole moments and bond orders. We train a set of machine learning potentials on it and demonstrate that they can achieve chemical accuracy across a broad region of chemical space. It can serve as a valuable resource for the creation of transferable, ready to use potential functions for use in molecular simulations.}, language = {en}, number = {1}, urldate = {2023-01-07}, journal = {Scientific Data}, author = {Eastman, Peter and Behara, Pavan Kumar and Dotson, David L. and Galvelis, Raimondas and Herr, John E. and Horton, Josh T. and Mao, Yuezhi and Chodera, John D. and Pritchard, Benjamin P. and Wang, Yuanqing and De Fabritiis, Gianni and Markland, Thomas E.}, month = jan, year = {2023}, note = {Number: 1 Publisher: Nature Publishing Group}, keywords = {Proteins, Molecular dynamics, Computational chemistry, Density functional theory}, pages = {11}, }
